bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 20, 1900

div1.p: Reed sees their son, Lawrence, in Havana. He enjoys a meal given for the English physicians. He discusses China news, and relays information about a transport from the States.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 20, 1900
div1.p:
I have
just returned from a very
pleasant drive to Havana,
via the pretty surburban
Village of Vedado. We drove
right by the Santa Clara
Battery, but didn't stop.
when we got to my truth-
ful Spanish Tailor's Shop,
whom should I meet but
the boy, all dressed up in
a suit of white with a
suit I white Helmet perched
on top of his cranium-
He looked cool, collected
and happy- Said that he had
ordered made for himself
a suit of kaki and another
of linen Crash- I told him
to order a second crash suit
and I would foot the bill,
whereat the smiled & said
he would not neglect to do
so- He promises to come
out on Sunday to spend
the day- We again just
missed a very heavy down-
pour of rain, on our return-
Indeed, we are having two
rains per day now- How
I wish that I could trans-
fer some of this moisture
to our hill-side- We called
on our English cousins
and invited them to come
out, tomorrow, to a 12 o'clock
breakfast. How is that for
style and general tone? The
bill of fare as arranged
by Mrs. Sharke, assisted
by myself, will be about
as follows: A Horn of 1841
Brandy with Soda - Soup
a la China - Red Snapper
with sauce inimitable.
Saratoga potatoes - Old Scotch
whisky served in glasses
stolen from the Governor
General's palace - Potato
salad - scotch whisky with
cracked-ice & Belfast ginger
ale - Black coffee - followed
by old scotch plain & un-
diluted - slow music!
Don't you think that this bill
should loosen their heart-
strings a little? Just here in
comes little Ramon, the small
Jap boy, with a helmet that
some soldier has given him
perched on his head, hind
part before- He calls me
his friend & pats me on the
back very affectionately-
It is astonishing how he is
picking up English- Pointing
to little daughter's picture, he
said “la ija de usted”?
I told him yes; that she was
my little baby girl, at which
he laughed heartily- I never
saw anyone more interes-
ted in anything than he is
over the trouble in China.
We hear, to-day, that the le-
gations are all safe- What
glorious news after the dread-
ful suspense of the last 3 weeks,
we only hope that it is true;
still one cannot believe any-
thing he sees in the news papers.
I went in to see General
Humphreys about the date of
the sailing of the next transport
from New York- He said that
he didn't know, but would
Cable & find out, and then send
me word- Dr Stark says that
an officer, who expects his
wife down, has told him
that a steamer leaves New
York on July 25th, as I stated
in my morning's letter.
The lunch-bell sounds and
I must stop to take aboard
a little fuel- Will finish
this to the sweetest woman in the morning.
Saturday Morning - July 21st 1900.
Well, sweetest Fat Farmer-
lady, if I overslept myself
a wee little bit, this morning,
you must really excuse me.
The Postman will soon be
here & I as I don't want
my letter to miss the boat,
I must bring it to a very
abrupt ending- I hope
that you will “exsqueeze”
old Mr Mantee this time.
The night was a little warm
& I didn't get to sleep as early
as usual- Give much love to
Sis Jane Motts and Helen-
Hope to get three or four letters
from my precious girls, this
morning- Love & Kisses for my
darling children.
